[GRAMMAR]: "Hebrew is one example among many of a language outliving for purposes of ritual its use in ordinary speech" (awkward phrasing and grammatical structure)
"The language in which it is framed continues fixed, amid the slowly developing conditions of the workaday world" (missing article and awkward phrasing)
"you will found the service conducted in a language" (incorrect verb form; should be "find")
"has been learn by them only for the purposes of the liturgy" (incorrect verb form; should be "learned")
"To render this possible the work of scholars such as Arthur Davis has contributed" (awkward phrasing and missing preposition)
"Part of the profits that accrued from the publication of 'The Services of the Synagogue' has been devoted" (subject-verb agreement issue; "has" should be "have")
"is to was delivered to-day by the most distinguished of lived Jewish men of letters" (incorrect verb form; should be "is to be delivered" and "lived" should be "living")

[LOGIC]: Sudden shift from discussing Arthur Davis to the broader topic of Hebrew as a ritual language without clear transition
The transition from discussing the revival of Hebrew to the claim that it is the only ritual language to have done so is abrupt and lacks sufficient support
The shift from discussing Arthur Davis's character to the claim that the Jews are a "Chosen People" in the next chapter is abrupt and lacks a clear connection
[STRUCTURE]: The text jumps between historical examples of ritual languages and the specific case of Hebrew without clear organization
[CLARITY]: The metaphor of "roses of Jericho" is introduced without sufficient explanation, making it confusing for readers unfamiliar with the reference

[GRAMMAR]: "David, who is promised of God that his seed shall was enthroned for ever" (subject-verb agreement error)

"Every Saturday night the orthodox Jew repeated the prayer..." (passive voice and tense inconsistency)
"And here we see the absurdity of judged the Bible outside its historic conditions" (missing preposition or incorrect verb form)
